commentBody: Quick but fun

I love learning useful things from crosswords. 
I never knew the band NSYNC was actually *NSYNC.

Thank you, Hanh.
You're a STAR.

I *ted to figure it out as soon as QBERT didn't fit properly.

Relatively easy once you figure out the rebus.

This was a good one. Wasted about 2 minutes because I forgot how to spell *NSYNC, or I would have been close to my Thursday record.

True story… I almost missed THE *RY NIGHT when I visited New York for the first time around Christmas. It was in the only part of MoMA I hadn’t walked through. If I hadn’t seen the postcard in the gift shop, I surely would have left without seeing it. (For more on this topic, listen to Taylor Tomlinson’s “I don’t think so, honey” rant from the Las Culturistas podcast.)
I tried to make “re(star)t it” work for far too long (instead of reboot).
Cute. But a Corner piece is a rook, not a castle. Castle is a chess term but it’s not the name of a piece.
Today I learned that PAREN is a thing. If I said PAREN are a thing, that'd be plural, then they'd be PARENTHESES. I'm still confused, but here we are.
This was a super cute one!

Great puzzle! 

I’m frustrated, tho, at the app’s inability to accept just the first letter of the rebus entry, like I’m pretty sure it’s supposed to? Seems like it’s happened in the last few rebus puzzles that I’ve done. I get to the end and have to go back and put in all of the letters for the rebus (or in this case the * or the full word). 

Why does it work for some puzzles but not others?

I, too, fell for the cUTLET trap. At least I'm in good company...

(Also had altho before PAREN, and n*SYNC, so that corner was awkward.)

My first thought for 28A didn't fit, and I couldn't think of a 5-letter equivalent, but when the same thing happened at 36A (less certainly) and 48A, it occurred to me to check the day. That it was a Thursday  puzzle reassured me.  By Q*BERT I was confident enough to fill in the letters (leaving a space), and once I got M*A*S*H I went back to fill in the asterisk. 

Fun puzzle. I approve!

Pretty nice, simple, easy theme.  (Maybe too easy.)

My own only holdup was in the center, where unknotting afghans (not angora) and eft (not ent) and HRs (not PRs) all took me too long.  Pretty fun overall.

___________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

I was naticked by E_T crossing _AR_S, and that in turn crossing _[STAR]BERT. I have no idea what EBT is, I've never heard of BARQS (those random letter salad American brands are impossible to guess if you simply dont know them), and Q*BERT was another mystery to me - I may be a gamer, and I've played hundreds of games over nearly 40 years, but not this one. I only managed to get out of this bind by looking up that brand name...

That's a shame, because other than that I found this to be an enjoyable puzzle with a clever yet gettable theme. I did not know E_TRADE and _NSYNC featured stars in their names, and I was unfamiliar with M*A*S*H statistics, but unlike the natick described above, I was able to figure these entries out.

Great puzzle!
CO* / *NSYNC was the giveaway for me, so it all fell into place pretty quickly on the first pass.

Neat construction. But. But: I went through the clues after I finished just to confirm my initial impression, and yes: You can complete this puzzle having never read a single book. 

And yes, I may be crabby because I got stuck in the NW after entering EdD for 1D. My 4am brain stared at the dAR_S / _*BERT cross and said, “I got nuthin.’”

I know, I know. EBT and BARQS should fill in without a second thought because we all go to the grocery store, but I live inside my head and the only time I come alive when I’m buying food is in the produce section. Okay, and maybe the beer cooler… I haven’t thought about BARQS—or QBERT—since I was a kid. Those neurons have since atrophied. 

It took me a long time to flyspeck and realize I confused the EBT label at the checkout stand with the ubiquitous EDT signs on people’s lawns. Sigh. 

So yes, I appreciate the Thursdayness of the puzzle; I just wasn’t blown away by the fill. 

And now I’m going back to bed. Happy Thursday, everyone.
Can someone please explain 35 down to me?

Time to complete 99% of puzzle correctly: 20 minutes

Time to pore over the puzzle three times, have a gnawing feeling that CUTLETS is wrong, give up, and read this article: 12 additional minutes
Left me *ry eyed, very fun and satisfying!
Thank you for a super fun Thursday! Very reluctant to let go of “Waterlilies” for 17 across. Loved the M*A*S*H reference—must see TV with Mum growing up.
Really enjoyed it and set a Thursday PR, maybe because I’m just the right age for Q*bert, *Nsync, and Rambo.

That was ★tlingly good, especially the virtuoso use of M★A★S★H. I'm one of those misguided ba★ds who never cared for that show, never got its appeal until too late. Don't ★e at me like that! We all can't cut the mu★d like you do! 

I did watch the final episode of the Sopranos, though, and loved that show, not only for its ★s but even more for all the bit players just ★ting their careers. 

There you go again. THE Starry Night. THE Mona Lisa. I'm never ★ved for things that get me ★ted these days. Might as well add this to the list. Pour moi, there ain't no the there. But panning out for the big picture, you really think Van Gogh was a ★k raving lunatic? A professor here in town spent years researching a particular form of epilepsy and its effects on vision and perspective. He partly convinced me that Van Gogh's medical condition caused those crazy skies and off-kilter chairs & tables. And I was like, yeah, but there's only one Van Gogh. Now, if you'll excuse me I'm going to have a piece of my wife★te au pomme.

(Second attempt...) What a stellar M*A*S*H up of fill and rebuses! And, frankly, any puzzle that has that brilliant series in it wins my heart. Add to it Van Gogh's The Starry Night, and I'm ooh-ing and aah-ing. (In honor of the latter, here's Don McLean with "Vincent," emoting the lyrics with all his soul, very much more seasoned in 1999 than he was in 1972: https://youtu.be/XDfgBEB-qEk?si=IG8akUL318XZm4rN) Come Thursdays, it's like I have a solving sky inside of me that gets colored by golden sunrises and sunsets, but today it went even farther and got lit up with splendid stars. Thank you, Mr. Huynh!

Wow, what a uniquely clever and fun puzzle! Hands down my favorite Thursday so far this year.

I’m thrilled that the greatest TV series of all-time, M*A*S*H, finally appears as an entry with the title accurately represented. Well done!

The Q crossing was tricky.  Thankfully I pulled BARQ’S from the dark recesses of my brain, since I'm unfamiliar with Q*BERT.  I can see where that could be troublesome for some solvers. 

Congratulations, Hanh. You are a *.
OK. So I see from comments that it's a gimmie for some, but would a kind American solver care to explain to us in the rest of the world how the (bleep) EBT is an answer?
BRILLIANT!!

Another potential natick-lite at the 23 across/down intersection: what if HAZE and HPI? I had no idea about DPI so it was 50/50 whether to fill that square with D or H. What does DPI even mean? Dots… pixels… image!? Best I’ve got.

It's nice to be nice to the nice....  (Frank Burns) and this was very nice!! 

Super duper fast, more than a few SECs but  not a whole lot more, but it was really fun and I enjoyed it the theme a lot! Kind of wish it would have taken me a little longer, because it was that nice. And I don't speed solve anything, it just went fast.

Two of my favorites showed up: *RYNIGHT and M*A*S*H, which was my dead giveaway. Although, when it obviously didn't fit, I wondered if something had replaced it in all these years... Seinfeld!? Nope! Came back to it after rereading the revealer, which I normally don't pay attention to until I've done I go through of all acrosses and downs first to fill in what I can immediately and got it at that point.

Imagine if he could have added *TREK. I'd be over the moon and dancing among the ******!
One of my first Halloween costumes as a kid was Q*BERT!  Love seeing it here!
Not sure if the Top Gun references were a very last minute homage or a happy coincidence, but either way, RIP Ice Man.

Agree with Jeff as to wondering if the Top Gun references were changed to fit or just happened to coincide. RIP Batman, Ice Man, Mad Martigen. Neat bit of Trivia, in the summer of 89 or 90 he played Hamlet in the Colorado Shakespeare Festival 

I prefer Barqs to Mug so that was a gimme. Mash I knew and had to pause for a moment to remember the *s. Once I figured that out, very early on it made for a very quick Thursday

I took a bit of a rest because I was *ting to feel like the first person who had a go at yesterday's puzzle, entering almost right, possibly right, not right fills. I'm back now. 

Only two flat-out mistakes, a couple of demystifications from Deb (thank you!), and one look-up (never played video games) and it's done.  

Thank you for this astral trip Hanh Huynh!  A beauty of a puzzle, once the scales dropped from my eyes and I saw *****.
To spend some time with "The Starry Night," here's what MoMA has to say: https://www.moma.org/collection/works/79802
I enjoyed this puzzle overall and found it pretty intuitive, so it's a shame that the last word I completed and thus the final impression I was left with was the truly awful PARENS.

Clever, witty, fun, I had a blast.

Buuuttt, I did need to run the alphabet with the cross at 12A and 13D.  I had no clue for either entry.  Naticked my behind off.

But I enjoyed myself, start to finish.  And I can't ask for more than that.
This was a MASHterpiece!!

C’mon, there must have been others that wrote in STARRYNIGHT before figuring out the theme and that it was THE[STAR]RYNIGHT.

As for red EFTs, they are quite common around here in the spring. I would never have thought of them as crosswordese.

And I was completely cUTLET-ed too until I figured that out to finish the puzzle. 🤓

Gold ⭐️ and two thumbs up 👍🏼👍🏼 for this one. I had a couple of wrong turns here to start. I chose A AND W before BARQS and N*SYNC before *NSYNC. The placement of that * really matters 😆🤦🏼‍♀️ My final correction came at the end…hAZE to DAZE and voila! Gold ⭐️😮‍💨😅 
Fun puzzle today!!

"Did you win the astronomy competition?"
"No. Just got a constellation prize."

(These puns provide cosmic relief.)

I don't usually do the puzzle the night before its published day, but my dog hates storms and I'm listening to loud, familiar TV until it passes. So I chuckled when I heard from this guy. https://futurama.fandom.com/wiki/Cubert_J._Farnsworth

Newsflash: Rebuses are painless

Visions of squished-in words to be
Heaven's vaults ONTAP for me
I realize and I can see...

That rebuses are painless
They bring on kooky changes
And you can N⭐️SYNC those stars if you please

Sometimes crosswords are hard to play
My streak has STRAYED, but that's OK
I'm Q⭐️BERT with no grawlix today
Just REBOOT that grid and play away!

Cause rebuses are painless
Unlike if SUMOS rearranged us
And I can take or leave that if I please.

Sussing BAHRAIN made my head spin
So here's a tip in one PAREN...
(Autocheck is not a sin, it's a CO⭐️ to help you win)

Rebuses are painless
I'll chug Sarsaparilla 'cause it's nameless
and I can take or leave brands if I please.

My tired spouse asks how can it be
A Thursday grid BUTTSIN on sleep
"So you didn't win,  just let it be"
and I replied, "It ⭐️CROSSED ME!"

(Yes, I know it works on paper.)
Very cute.  Also had no idea that NSYNC was (is?) *NSYNC.  Nicely done.
Heaven! Thanks Hanh.
Maybe SUMOS (43A) is a word used colloquially by some English speakers for sumo wrestlers, but the generally accepted word is RIKISHI, from the Japanese.

Gosh, EBT crossing BARQS crossing QBERT was a complete Natick for me. 

Not familiar with BARQS. Now that I see QBERT it’s possibly a word I’ve heard but I couldn’t have told you what it is. Though that’s not even the first result that comes up (for me). 

Shame because I thought the theme for this puzzle was a great idea! 
Especially enjoyed finding MASH down the middle containing *three* of the theme boxes all in one entry.

But please don't reveal the theme in the Tricky clues section. You normally don't do that, and it's great because we can get a little help with the tricky clues and still discover the theme on our own. 
But today, the very first Tricky clue entry told us about the rebus and * entry. 
If you have to, at least put a spoiler warning, please? 
Best wishes to all of you from Denmark

I posted earlier but it never showed up. Anyway -clever puzzle and a fun solve. Took me a bit to catch on, but then just had a good time filling it all in. And... puzzle find today: A Sunday from March 29, 1992 by Ernst Theimer with the title "Symbols." Never seen another one like this. Some crossing clue/answer examples: 13d."WHY SHE CANNOT MAKE ZWIEBACK" HERTOASTERISKAPUT crossing.. 39a:"LUCKY FIDO, ABOUT HIS OWNER" NOMASTERISKINDER Except - those were actually entered as: HERTO*APUT and NOM*INDER Some other theme answers: ASA(PARENTHESES)TIMABLE ASA()TIMABLE crossing ITSAPPARENTHESESKIMO ITAP()KIMO And lots more. Hard to describe beyond that. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=3/29/1992&g=39&d=A ...

I was unable to find a (bootlegged) pdf of his short story "Letters to the Editore," but for anyone familiar with the works of Donald Barthelme, today would be a good day to read it.

(It's in the collection *Fourty Stories*, if not elsewhere).

My comment from last night never appeared, so here’s another version.  Having Hires instead of BARQS, starrynight instead of THE*RYNIGHT, and never having heard of Q*BERT made the NW a mess to decipher.  Then when I “finished” I got the pesky something’s amiss message.  Try as I might I couldn’t find my mistake, so I changed all the rebuses from STAR  to *.  Still no luck.  Eventually, I changed haze to DAZE and voila!  I enjoyed every minute of this one, even the final frustration.

I go to MOMA once a year, drawn by THESTARRYNIGHT (and Three Musicians and The Persistence Of Memory).  This year I went with my art conservator daughter, who had gotten us tickets to the special exhibition, a showing of Christian Marclay’s The Clock.  It’s a 24 hour film that plays continuously and is composed of brief clips of other films or tv shows that feature clocks showing the time. It’s synchronized so that the time showing corresponds to the local time where you are watching.  We watched for about an hour and a half and it was mesmerizing.

A real mix of fabulous Ahas and impenetrable US specificisms for me. As always, NYTXWD is perfectly correct and entitled to include those, but oh the headache they induce in the rest of us. I’m being careful how I write the above, as some of my posts have been lost to the ether. 

DH and I were a part of the tv audience to watch that final episode of MASH. I’m assuming that’s the one as the record breaking thing is new to me. I laughed and cried and never wanted it to end. Thanks for the memory.

Took me forever to get the theme; 17A threw me as STARRY NIGHT fit perfectly and I had nothing in the crosses. It was 28A that finally gave me the in. I had STAR instead of * as the rebus, but changed it once I got to the tv show. A brilliant Aha.

4A gave me the biggest chuckle, only because I mis-read the clue as True Blood. I turned myself inside out trying to fit a character name in there. MIGS showed me my error, but I needed pilot and general plane nerd DH’s help for the US plane.

Thank you Mr Huynh for a truly enjoyable Thursday.

I still managed to get the happy music more than 9 min faster than my average Thursday time, so I think this was an easier than usual puzzle.

Very enjoyable though, and quite clever!

I guess my steak ends at 333 days.  No idea where I am off; I’ve tried 4 different ways to enter *s in the puzzle.  No clue what the bottom right corner clues mean, but I’ve tried every letter in that corner to no avail.  Oh well.  Maybe I will come back to this later with fresh eyes.
Really enjoyable!!

Finished wayyyy over whatever
my average time may be.

Not because the puzzle was unfair.
Or because of the rebus.

It’s because printers hate me.
To be fair, they also hate my family.

Our system is to-

purchase a printer,
get it working,
print something,
feel *cautiously* optimistic,
try to print something else a few days later,
spend 3 hours taking turns trouble shooting,
another hour taking turns cursing and sobbing,
print *nothing*,
go to Staples and get our print,
toss our printer,
wait a year,
repeat.

So hPI, DPI, DAZE/hAZE took 
forrrreverrrr to find.

Closest I’ve gotten to breaking my 
no-lookup streak yet.

Loved the puzzle.
Loved M*A*S*H, and remember that episode well.

My first iteration of this comment went the way of the dodo bird, so here it is again:

I caught on to the theme right away, first with cuSTARD, then with E*TRADE. That company was my first tentative entry into having to learn about finances in about a minute and a half after my divorce. First thing I did was sell a bond that was paying 12½% interest. Duh.

Now back to the puzzle. But then I got bogged down and sort of forgot that only the across answers had to spell out the word STAR (or the equivalent asterisk). I knew the answer to 25 down had to be MASH. But never having watched that episode, or any other, for that matter, I really had no clue that each letter was followed by an asterisk. That was my punishment for staying up to do the puzzle at 5 a.m., instead of like normal people, who do it earlier and go to sleep, or get up early and do it with a morning cup of coffee. But I was born a night owl and I'll never change. Wish I could post a pic of my LLBean Night Owl slippers (purchased long before the boycott!) Finally did figure it out, whew, since that was the only answer holding me back.

I loved this puzzle.  What can I say I’m a sucker for a rebus.  I screwed myself royally by putting starry night, which so obviously right, but made the NW incomprehensible, complicated by the fact that I knew nothing about Q*BERT.  On the other hand, M*A*S*H was a gimme, so I caught on to the rebus. I typed Star into each rebus spot, and when I “finished” the puzzle I got the dreaded almost done message.  I couldn’t find my mistake, so I went back and substituted * for Star.  Still wrong.  Finally I saw my error: haze instead of DAZE.  

Despite that, I had a blast with this one, and any puzzle with THESTARRYNIGHT is Aok in my book.  I make it a point to visit MOMA every year specifically to see THESTARRYNIGHT (as well as Picasso’s Three Musicians and Dali’s Persistence Of Memory).  This year I went in January and got a bonus.  My daughter had arranged for us to get in to watch Christian Marclay’s The Clock.  It’s a 24 hour film composed entirely of short clips of shots of clocks taken from other movies or tv shows, and synchronized to local time, so that the clips show the correct time.  I watched for an hour and a half and found it quite mesmerizing.

For this bidirectional puzzle, where there are squares that have different across and down answers, I’ll leave my obligatory comment grousing about inconsistencies in accepted formatting for bidirectional puzzles.

This is one of the puzzles which doesn’t accept “Across/Down” formatting — though it accepts “STAR” or “\*”, it doesn’t accept “STAR/\*”. While “STAR” and “\*” could be considered equivalent to each other, the answers aren’t literally the same. 

In my opinion, “Across/Down” formatting should always be accepted, unless there is a very good reason not to. I personally prefer to have a verbose, completionist fill.

Currently,  “Across/Down” formatting is accepted more often than not, but on occasion it isn’t, like for this one, and a similar one late last year that used lines/hyphens. In either case of it being accepted or not, it is annoying when fiddling with an incomplete puzzle, wondering whether it’s the formatting or the other answers that are tripping me up.

Would it be possible to always accept “Across/Down” formatting, or release some sort of style guide where cases of accepted and non accepted formatting is explained?

@B - As an erstwhile paid proofreader, I can assure you that paren / parens is not slang; it is exactly what is used in editing, proofing, and publishing. Call it argot, perhaps, and I would sympathize. But argot isn’t the same as slang.

We read proof in pairs, one person speaking the one text aloud while the other pays close attention to the other text by eye. One text is what was sent to the printer, the other what came back.

So a sentence that looks like:
The final episode of M*A*S*H had (inarguably) the highest real-time viewership.
would be spoken as
The final episode of mash cap-M star cap-A star cap-S star cap-H mash had open-paren inarguably close-paren the highest real hyph time viewership peer.

Comma - com
Colon - cole
Semicolon - semi
“” - open/close double-quote
Apostrophe - aposs
Exclamation point - bang
Abbreviated - abbreev
etc. - et cetera abbreev ee tee cee peer

AFGHAN was a gimme - compared to the West, there were few dog breeds in Poland in my 1980s childhood behind the Iron Curtain. For example, labs (like Jorge the Lab whom I can hear snoring in the living room as I'm writing this having woken up in the middle of the night), golden retrievers and yorkies only arrived here with democracy and market economy. Back then most Polish dogs were mixed breed (Max I and Max II, my childhood dogs, certainly were). Of the breeds I knew German shepherds, fox terriers, pekes, dachshunds, schnauzers, great Danes, Podhale shepherd (a Polish breed of large sheepdog, rarely encountered at present...) and - yes! - Afghan hounds, or rather one particular Afghan hound. I occasionally saw one being walked in our neighborhood by a striking woman in classic 1980s attire. Maybe she was a model? Anyway, that image is ingrained in my memory, and with it the name of the breed 🙂

The same can be said about Lin-MANUEL Miranda for non-theater buffs, Agnus DEI for non-Catholics and Latin speakers, MIGS for non-movie buffs, etc.

Or not.

To answer your question, there are a couple of indications. 

First, today is Thursday, so that means there is some kind of trick.  This can happen other days as well, but some type of twist is almost guaranteed on a Thursday.

Second, you'll notice that answers that you are pretty sure of don't fit in the allocated boxes.  

Once you know to expect something like this, it gets considerably easier, and for many solvers, something to look forward to.
